qas.question: Who argued for Americans to use the term "African American"?
What year did Jesse Jackson make this argument?
Why did Jackson want this term to be used?

answers.text: it had a historical cultural base and was a construction similar to terms used by European descendants

qas.question: Who also argued for the term "African American"?
Why did some argue that "black" was the better term?

context: In <a1_0>1988<a1_0/>, the civil rights leader <a0_0>Jesse Jackson<a0_0/> urged Americans to use instead the term "African American" because <a2_0>it had a historical cultural base and was a construction similar to terms used by European descendants<a2_0/>, such as German American, Italian American, etc. Since then, African American and black have often had parallel status. However, controversy continues over which if any of the two terms is more appropriate. Maulana Karenga argues that the term <a3_0>African-American<a3_0/> is more appropriate because it accurately articulates their geographical and historical origin.[citation needed] Others have argued that "black" is a better term <a4_0>because "African" suggests foreignness<a4_0/>, although Black Americans helped found the United States. Still others believe that the term black is inaccurate because African Americans have a variety of skin tones. Some surveys suggest that the majority of Black Americans have no preference for "African American" or "Black", although they have a slight preference for "black" in personal settings and "African American" in more formal settings.
